content: Nope, it's just red - and probably a dead end, but I'm thinking of talking to a lawyer about suing my neighbors about their dog. there's got to be a legal recourse beyond just complaining to the police about the noise. the thing just as well be in our kitchen barking all the time - what an annoying racket!! Wandering and Wondering
reply: Nope, it's just red - and probably a dead end, but I'm thinking of talking to a lawyer about suing my neighbors about their dog. there's got to be a legal recourse beyond just complaining to the police about the noise. the thing just as well be in our kitchen barking all the time - what an annoying racket!! title: Are there any lawyers in the house?

content: quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: Nope, it's just red - and probably a dead end, but I'm thinking of talking to a lawyer about suing my neighbors about their dog. there's got to be a legal recourse beyond just complaining to the police about the noise. the thing just as well be in our kitchen barking all the time - what an annoying racket!! There is nothing more annoying than some yacking-azz dog and it's the dog's owner's responsibility to maintain his animal in the proper manner. Most towns have animal and noise ordinances. The animal barking statutes are usually not handled by the police, but by the dog warden or animal control officer. They know the statutes better than cops and are entrusted to summons dog owners for violations. Our statute prohibits "prolonged barking". A court ruling said prolonged exceeded 15 or 20 minutes. The animal control officer also will see if the dog is licensed. Unlicensed would be another violation. If summonses go unanswered, I have seen them confiscate an animal till the situation is resolved. They have asked for evidence, such as a video of the violation. Your information will be kept confidential because they know most complainants don't want a confrontation with a knucklehead dog owner. By all means call animal control soon. Tell them your friend Kevin told you to.
quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: Nope, it's just red - and probably a dead end, but I'm thinking of talking to a lawyer about suing my neighbors about their dog. there's got to be a legal recourse beyond just complaining to the police about the noise. the thing just as well be in our kitchen barking all the time - what an annoying racket!!

They know the statutes better than cops and are entrusted to summons dog owners for violations. Our statute prohibits "prolonged barking". A court ruling said prolonged exceeded 15 or 20 minutes. The animal control officer also will see if the dog is licensed. Unlicensed would be another violation. content: Bought one of these - seems to have some affect. It listens for the dog to bark, then emits a high=frequency irritating sound that only the dog can here to cause it to stop. Seems to have some affect at times...but I think the dog develops a tolerance after a time... Costs 50 dollars, so I'm paying paying to train their dog - ain't right! If I could sue them bad enough to take the property, I'd bulldoze the house . . . Wandering and Wondering

title: Are there any lawyers in the house?

content: quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: Bought one of these - seems to have some affect. It listens for the dog to bark, then emits a high=frequency irritating sound that only the dog can here to cause it to stop. Seems to have some affect at times...but I think the dog develops a tolerance after a time... Costs 50 dollars, so I'm paying paying to train their dog - ain't right! If I could sue them bad enough to take the property, I'd bulldoze the house . . . Do you know your neighbors? If not, perhaps it would be a good time to get to know them. Try first to start out on a friendly basis. Take over a some veggies from your garden or a cake (if the wife is a good baker). Lead the conversation to the point where you mention that their dog must be very unhappy. Try to find out why it is so unhappy. Perhaps the dog is sick or maybe they have a sick child or baby in the house. Surely the barking is loud to them as well as you. (It would not be recommended to say "your stupid dog barks all night and keeps me awake, I'm going to *****....******!") If the people are just downright rude...well then, start: dog barks = phone call (every time) If they ignore or unplug the phone, then do something that annoys the neighbor. Target practice in the back yard, annoying music, running a chainsaw, firecrackers...etc. Or perhaps you could remove parts of the fence so the unhappy dog be free from his unhappiness. Obviously you are being annoyed by the dog barking and the dog owners are oblivious to your annoyance. When they become inconvenienced or annoyed you will get their attention and be able to resolve the problem. "They love our milk and honey but they preach about some other way of living When you’re running down my country, Hoss you’re walking on the fighting side of me" - - Merle Haggard
quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: Bought one of these - seems to have some affect. If I could sue them bad enough to take the property, I'd bulldoze the house . . .

Try to find out why it is so unhappy. Perhaps the dog is sick or maybe they have a sick child or baby in the house. Surely the barking is loud to them as well as you. (It would not be recommended to say "your stupid dog barks all night and keeps me awake, I'm going to *****....******!") If the people are just downright rude...well then, start: dog barks = phone call (every time) If they ignore or unplug the phone, then do something that annoys the neighbor. Target practice in the back yard, annoying music, running a chainsaw, firecrackers...etc. Or perhaps you could remove parts of the fence so the unhappy dog be free from his unhappiness. Obviously you are being annoyed by the dog barking and the dog owners are oblivious to your annoyance. When they become inconvenienced or annoyed you will get their attention and be able to resolve the problem. content: quote: If they ignore or unplug the phone, then do something that annoys the neighbor. Target practice in the back yard, annoying music, running a chainsaw, firecrackers...etc. Or perhaps you could remove parts of the fence so the unhappy dog be free from his unhappiness. A good portion of that can cause the charges to go the other way - I just keep E-mailing the police, the mayor and the city council about the problem. They'll either fix it, or I'll have one helluva paper trail when the shyyt finally hits the fan - - Wandering and Wondering
quote: If they ignore or unplug the phone, then do something that annoys the neighbor. Target practice in the back yard, annoying music, running a chainsaw, firecrackers...etc. Or perhaps you could remove parts of the fence so the unhappy dog be free from his unhappiness.
reply: A good portion of that can cause the charges to go the other way - I just keep E-mailing the police, the mayor and the city council about the problem. They'll either fix it, or I'll have one helluva paper trail when the shyyt finally hits the fan - - Wandering and Wondering
title: Are there any lawyers in the house?

content: quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: quote: If they ignore or unplug the phone, then do something that annoys the neighbor. Target practice in the back yard, annoying music, running a chainsaw, firecrackers...etc. Or perhaps you could remove parts of the fence so the unhappy dog be free from his unhappiness. A good portion of that can cause the charges to go the other way - I just keep E-mailing the police, the mayor and the city council about the problem. They'll either fix it, or I'll have one helluva paper trail when the shyyt finally hits the fan - - GW, File a restraining order with the court. You will have to submit evidence of the annoying barking. When the court grants the order, any subsequent barking will be a violation of the court order, ie, contempt of court, and the neighbor will be fined. If it continues, after about three violations, the court will order the dog removed by animal control. You do not need a lawyer to do this. It is just a matter of filling out the forms and appearing in court. The sheriff can serve the neighbor with the notice to appear.
quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: quote: If they ignore or unplug the phone, then do something that annoys the neighbor. Target practice in the back yard, annoying music, running a chainsaw, firecrackers...etc. Or perhaps you could remove parts of the fence so the unhappy dog be free from his unhappiness. A good portion of that can cause the charges to go the other way - I just keep E-mailing the police, the mayor and the city council about the problem. They'll either fix it, or I'll have one helluva paper trail when the shyyt finally hits the fan - -
reply: GW, File a restraining order with the court. You will have to submit evidence of the annoying barking. When the court grants the order, any subsequent barking will be a violation of the court order, ie, contempt of court, and the neighbor will be fined. If it continues, after about three violations, the court will order the dog removed by animal control. You do not need a lawyer to do this. It is just a matter of filling out the forms and appearing in court. The sheriff can serve the neighbor with the notice to appear.

content: quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: Nope, it's just red - and probably a dead end, but I'm thinking of talking to a lawyer about suing my neighbors about their dog. there's got to be a legal recourse beyond just complaining to the police about the noise. the thing just as well be in our kitchen barking all the time - what an annoying racket!! There is nothing more annoying than some yacking-azz dog and it's the dog's owner's responsibility to maintain his animal in the proper manner. Most towns have animal and noise ordinances. The animal barking statutes are usually not handled by the police, but by the dog warden or animal control officer. They know the statutes better than cops and are entrusted to summons dog owners for violations. Our statute prohibits "prolonged barking". A court ruling said prolonged exceeded 15 or 20 minutes. The animal control officer also will see if the dog is licensed. Unlicensed would be another violation. If summonses go unanswered, I have seen them confiscate an animal till the situation is resolved. They have asked for evidence, such as a video of the violation. Your information will be kept confidential because they know most complainants don't want a confrontation with a knucklehead dog owner. By all means call animal control soon. Tell them your friend Kevin told you to.

content: quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: Bought one of these - seems to have some affect. It listens for the dog to bark, then emits a high=frequency irritating sound that only the dog can here to cause it to stop. Seems to have some affect at times...but I think the dog develops a tolerance after a time... Costs 50 dollars, so I'm paying paying to train their dog - ain't right! If I could sue them bad enough to take the property, I'd bulldoze the house . . . Do you know your neighbors? If not, perhaps it would be a good time to get to know them. Try first to start out on a friendly basis. Take over a some veggies from your garden or a cake (if the wife is a good baker). Lead the conversation to the point where you mention that their dog must be very unhappy. Try to find out why it is so unhappy. Perhaps the dog is sick or maybe they have a sick child or baby in the house. Surely the barking is loud to them as well as you. (It would not be recommended to say "your stupid dog barks all night and keeps me awake, I'm going to *****....******!") If the people are just downright rude...well then, start: dog barks = phone call (every time) If they ignore or unplug the phone, then do something that annoys the neighbor. Target practice in the back yard, annoying music, running a chainsaw, firecrackers...etc. Or perhaps you could remove parts of the fence so the unhappy dog be free from his unhappiness. Obviously you are being annoyed by the dog barking and the dog owners are oblivious to your annoyance. When they become inconvenienced or annoyed you will get their attention and be able to resolve the problem. "They love our milk and honey but they preach about some other way of living When you’re running down my country, Hoss you’re walking on the fighting side of me" - - Merle Haggard
quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: Bought one of these - seems to have some affect. It listens for the dog to bark, then emits a high=frequency irritating sound that only the dog can here to cause it to stop. Seems to have some affect at times...but I think the dog develops a tolerance after a time... Costs 50 dollars, so I'm paying paying to train their dog - ain't right! If I could sue them bad enough to take the property, I'd bulldoze the house . . .

Try to find out why it is so unhappy. Perhaps the dog is sick or maybe they have a sick child or baby in the house. Surely the barking is loud to them as well as you. (It would not be recommended to say "your stupid dog barks all night and keeps me awake, I'm going to *****....******!") If the people are just downright rude...well then, start: dog barks = phone call (every time) If they ignore or unplug the phone, then do something that annoys the neighbor. Target practice in the back yard, annoying music, running a chainsaw, firecrackers...etc. Or perhaps you could remove parts of the fence so the unhappy dog be free from his unhappiness. Obviously you are being annoyed by the dog barking and the dog owners are oblivious to your annoyance. When they become inconvenienced or annoyed you will get their attention and be able to resolve the problem. "They love our milk and honey but they preach about some other way of living When you’re running down my country, Hoss you’re walking on the fighting side of me" - - Merle Haggard

content: quote: Originally posted by armywifefigueroa: Go buy an electric collar, walk up to the front door and tell them to use it or you'll permanently silence him... maybe that would ge the point across (btw, I'm no advacate for shooting animals unless it's for dinner, but sometimes the threat is enough to make the owners think about it) I have no problem shooting an animal, if it's attacking me, my family, or my pets. Where I live, the law states I can do that and I would not hesitate to do it. To kill an animal just to kill it, is totally wrong! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!

content: quote: If they ignore or unplug the phone, then do something that annoys the neighbor. Target practice in the back yard, annoying music, running a chainsaw, firecrackers...etc. Or perhaps you could remove parts of the fence so the unhappy dog be free from his unhappiness. A good portion of that can cause the charges to go the other way - I just keep E-mailing the police, the mayor and the city council about the problem. They'll either fix it, or I'll have one helluva paper trail when the shyyt finally hits the fan - - Wandering and Wondering
quote: If they ignore or unplug the phone, then do something that annoys the neighbor. Target practice in the back yard, annoying music, running a chainsaw, firecrackers...etc. Or perhaps you could remove parts of the fence so the unhappy dog be free from his unhappiness.
reply: A good portion of that can cause the charges to go the other way - I just keep E-mailing the police, the mayor and the city council about the problem. They'll either fix it, or I'll have one helluva paper trail when the shyyt finally hits the fan - - Wandering and Wondering
title: Are there any lawyers in the house?

content: quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: quote: If they ignore or unplug the phone, then do something that annoys the neighbor. Target practice in the back yard, annoying music, running a chainsaw, firecrackers...etc. Or perhaps you could remove parts of the fence so the unhappy dog be free from his unhappiness. A good portion of that can cause the charges to go the other way - I just keep E-mailing the police, the mayor and the city council about the problem. They'll either fix it, or I'll have one helluva paper trail when the shyyt finally hits the fan - - GW, File a restraining order with the court. You will have to submit evidence of the annoying barking. When the court grants the order, any subsequent barking will be a violation of the court order, ie, contempt of court, and the neighbor will be fined. If it continues, after about three violations, the court will order the dog removed by animal control. You do not need a lawyer to do this. It is just a matter of filling out the forms and appearing in court. The sheriff can serve the neighbor with the notice to appear.
quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: quote: If they ignore or unplug the phone, then do something that annoys the neighbor. Target practice in the back yard, annoying music, running a chainsaw, firecrackers...etc. Or perhaps you could remove parts of the fence so the unhappy dog be free from his unhappiness. A good portion of that can cause the charges to go the other way - I just keep E-mailing the police, the mayor and the city council about the problem. They'll either fix it, or I'll have one helluva paper trail when the shyyt finally hits the fan - -
reply: GW, File a restraining order with the court. You will have to submit evidence of the annoying barking. When the court grants the order, any subsequent barking will be a violation of the court order, ie, contempt of court, and the neighbor will be fined. If it continues, after about three violations, the court will order the dog removed by animal control. You do not need a lawyer to do this. It is just a matter of filling out the forms and appearing in court. The sheriff can serve the neighbor with the notice to appear.
title: Are there any lawyers in the house?

She wants to wander.... So had to have the son go dig out the ditch. He wasn't too happy. Ended up that he had to use a hoe between the bars dragging dirt to one side.
